org.jtrim2.event

Class OneShotListenerManager<ListenerType,ArgType>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jtrim2.event.OneShotListenerManager<ListenerType,ArgType>
  • Type Parameters:
    ListenerType - the type of the event handlers can possibly be added to the container
    ArgType - the type of the argument which can be passed to event handlers by the onEvent method
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    ListenerRegistry<ListenerType>, SimpleListenerRegistry<ListenerType>

    public final class OneShotListenerManager<ListenerType,ArgType>
extends Object
implements ListenerRegistry<ListenerType>
    A ListenerRegistry implementation which will automatically unregister listeners once they have been notified by an onEvent call. No listener will be notified more than once unless the listener has been added multiple times. Listeners will not even be notified multiple times, even if the onEvent method is called more than once.

    This implementation is useful for events which can trigger only once. A termination event is a typical example for an event which can occur only once (if restart is not possible).

    If you need to notify the listener even if the event has been dispatched previously, consider using the registerOrNotifyListener method.

    Thread safety

    As required by ListenerManager, the methods of this class are safe to be accessed concurrently by multiple threads.

    Synchronization transparency

    As required by ListenerManager, except for the onEvent method, methods of this class are synchronization transparent.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      OneShotListenerManager()
      Creates a new OneShotListenerManager with no listeners registered.

    • Method Detail

      • onEvent

        public void onEvent(EventDispatcher<? super ListenerType,? super ArgType> eventDispatcher,
                    ArgType arg)
        Invokes the onEvent method of the specified EventDispatcher with the currently registered listeners and the argument specified unless this method has already been called. If this method has already been called, then calling this method has no effect. That is, this method call is idempotent.

        The onEvent method is called synchronously in the current thread.

        The order in which the listener are notified is undefined. Also note, that multiply added listener might be notified multiple times depending on the exact implementation.

        Parameters:
        eventDispatcher - the EventDispatcher whose onEvent method is to be called for every registered listener with the specified argument. The onEvent method will be called as many times as many currently registered listeners are (i.e.: the number the getListenerCount() method returns). This argument cannot be null.
        arg - the argument to be passed to every invocation of the onEvent method of the specified EventDispatcher. This argument can be null if the EventDispatcher allows for null arguments.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - thrown if the specified EventDispatcher is null
        See Also:
        TaskScheduler

      • registerOrNotifyListener

        public ListenerRef registerOrNotifyListener(ListenerType listener)
        Adds an event listener to this container or notifies the listener if onEvent has already been called and returns a reference which can later be used to removed the listener added. To notify the listener, the EventDispatcher and the argument from the last onEvent call will be used.

        If the onEvent is always called with the same arguments, this method is effectively the same as calling the registerListener and then the onEvent method. Although this method is more efficient.

        Parameters:
        listener - the listener to be added to this container and be notified in subsequent event notifications method calls. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        the reference which can be used to remove the currently added listener. This method never returns null.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - thrown if the specified listener is null

      • registerListener

        public ListenerRef registerListener(ListenerType listener)
        Adds an event listener to this container and returns a reference which can later be used to removed the listener added.

        Subsequent event notifications will notify the added listener unless it is removed using the returned reference.

        It doesn't matter if the listener was already added. In case the given listener have been added to this ListenerRegistry it will be added again causing the added listener to be notified as many times as it has been added. Note that the equals method of the listener should have no effect regarding this ListenerRegistry.

        If a listener is removed but it was added multiple times, it will be removed only once. So, further event notifications will be delivered to the listener one less time.

        Specified by:
        registerListener in interface ListenerRegistry<ListenerType>
        Specified by:
        registerListener in interface SimpleListenerRegistry<ListenerType>
        Parameters:
        listener - the listener to be added to this container and be notified in subsequent event notifications method calls. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        the reference which can be used to remove the currently added listener. This method never returns null.

      • getListenerCount

        public int getListenerCount()
        Returns the number of currently added but not yet removed listeners.
        Specified by:
        getListenerCount in interface ListenerRegistry<ListenerType>
        Returns:
        the number of currently added but not yet removed listeners. This method always returns an integer greater than or equal to zero.
